entry.title: Day 502: Sunset
entry.content:
Every once in a while I find something fascinating that just has to go into a story. There's always something going on in the universe, and some of those things we get to lay eyes on thanks to the rovers on mars like Curiosity, which captured this event:

https://www.popsci.com/science/mars-shimmering-clouds/

I've never seen a sunset that color before! I'm definitely writing this one into something.

Thank you for reading,

Benjamin Hawley

entry.title: Day 501: Busy Day Today
entry.content:
I've now entered myself into so many competitions that they're all starting to happen on top of each other. Ok, it's only three, but hey one of them requires I write three separate stories, and I have to peer judge for two of them. With all that and the regular writing, I almost forgot to write the blog. Not that I'm complaining or anything. They've been a lot of fun, and I'm excited for this writers' conference right around the corner in March too.

Looks like I'll be busy for a while, so I guess I'd better get used to it!

Thank you for reading,

Benjamin Hawley

entry.title: Day 500!
entry.content:
Hey, it snuck up on me! This is the 500th day of Dangerous Day Job. I almost can't believe it. Very nearly two years now since I started this blog, I find myself wondering how it all went by so fast. It's been an amazing time in my life where I've really gotten to follow my dreams. I've written some good stories (even published a couple), met some cool people, made some good friends, and most importantly, had a blast along the way. I'm happy to say it's the best decision I ever made.

Which will remain the case right up until I run out of money and find myself on the street. I'll probably turn to a reluctant life of crime after society rejects my talents, break bad and move to Gotham where I can setup my new syndicate and taunt Batman by leaving obscure literary references at the scene of all my crimes. Either way, everything will work out in my favor, I'm sure.

Well, it's back to the ol' grindstone for me. I'm happy I got my new blog out in time for Day 500, but there's quite a bit of work to be done still. The email system is still on my todo list. I'm not sure they aren't going out, but I signed myself up and it just doesn't work for some reason. Hopefully I'll get it solved by Monday!

Thank you for reading,

Benjamin Hawley

entry.title: Day 498: Random Writing Blocks
entry.content:
Didn't get much done today. Sometimes I have these short slumps where I can't seem to write very much. I usually try to keep some momentum going on a daily basis but it doesn't always carry over very well. The blog has certainly been helpful for giving me something to fall back on to get the juices flowing again though. There's always something new to explore and write about.

Like today I was gathering some ideas for small bits of world building by watching one of my favorite YouTube channels, Tasting History. I can't ever get enough of his videos. Food and history is a great combo, and the production reminds me of old Discovery Channel shows that were actually informative. The histories behind the foods are always such great stories, and I like working similar little stories into my own worlds to add some authenticity. It's hard to beat the value that a recipe offers to connect people across continents and centuries. I noticed recently while reading the Green Bone Saga from Fonda Lee that she often uses little pieces of lore like recipes, commonly known stories, and even widespread company brands to create minor connections between characters. It creates this really convincing web of small commonalities between friends and enemies that all contribute to a sense of culture. This technique made the shock of visiting another continent feel so real, something that happens a few times over the series. Clever details like that never fails to make me want to go write again!

Thank you for reading,

Benjamin Hawley

entry.title: Day 497: Judgement Cast!
entry.content:
I just finished judging my first round of writing battle submissions and it was a lot of fun. The stories were better than I was expecting and I thought both participants did a great job. I can't mention any specifics, but the genre I was judging for was 'aliens.' I love aliens in fiction and the responses were both creative and fun so I couldn't really ask for more. The feedback system on the website is really straightforward and I can't wait to read my own when the round is finished. I'm sure it'll be helpful.

I read my submission back and on a second look, I don't think it's very good. The pacing is kinda off and the subject matter is not my usual cup of tea, but I was feeling adventurous while writing. Hopefully its clunkiness isn't held against me too badly. That three day time limit is brutal! I don't think I'll win, but I'm sure to get some good feedback.

Thank you for reading,

Benjamin Hawley

entry.title: Day 496: Progress Update
entry.content:
I'm up late on a Monday again. Yesterday I submitted to the latest writing battle and I think I used up a lot of my brain power. Today I haven't been able to write much of anything. Weird how it comes and goes.

I think I'm going to spend some more time on the blog, and start working on a new book haul. It's been a while since I've had one, but I've been trying not to break the bank lately so there's been good reason. My next book haul is going to focus on more modern titles, but this time I'm going to look for some good ones dang it. My last experiment with contemporary books was not very good, with the exception of discovering Abraham Verghese, who blew everybody else I read out of the water. I want to find some modern sci-fi titles to read, maybe some fantasy too. It'll be like getting back to my roots. Some of the first books I remember reading were sci-fi/fantasy published almost the same year I read them. Should be fun!

Thank you for reading,

Benjamin Hawley

entry.title: Day 495: Writing Battle Day 2
entry.content:
Well I was planning on using all my resources this time around, but the first prompt I got was Revenge - Leader - Suitcase, and that seems like the juiciest prompt I'm liable to get. I'm almost disappointed I didn't get to use my mulligans. This prompt has actually proved a different problem, in that I'm not sure how to choose between the many options the prompt presents. I've been blindsided and now I'm not sure how to proceed with only two days left to figure it out!

Thank you for reading,

Benjamin Hawley

entry.title: Day 294: The Writing Battle Starts Soon

link.title: Day 294: The Writing Battle Starts Soon

entry.content:
The writing battle starts right after this post! You can still join in right here up until the second day of the competition.

I'm excited to see what prompt I get this time. Something I didn't realize until reviewing the rules again today is that this competition is actually peer judged, meaning I'll have to read through several of my competitor's short stories to rank them against one another. I'm sure to read some good stuff over the next couple of weeks! I'm hoping that as the rounds go on, the decisions will get harder and harder as I read better and better stories. In the end, it better be a real nail biter.

Thank you for reading,

Benjamin Hawley

entry.title: Day 493: Blog Migration Continues
entry.content:
Today I've been puzzling over the best way to import images from WordPress to my new blog. After much thought, I think the real answer is 'only keep one blog, stupid,' but I'm hard headed and I need to keep this one at least until I can get the email service set up. The process of getting images over is still painful though, so I think I may avoid pictures for the next few days. The best part of the new blog is how customizable each blog post is since I can include anything I want using html and markdown, but that's also the problem. I have to put everything in myself if I want it to work. I can't seem to figure out how to export all the photos from this site easily so I end up having to fill in each and every photo manually by downloading them one at a time. It's about as far from ideal as I can get.

The email system should be more straightforward. Once it's set up, I should just be able to copy a list over from my current subscribers and continue sending out emails seamlessly. I'll also add a button to sign up on the blog once I get it going for new readers. After that, I should be ready to migrate over completely and host the blog from there then on out.

Thank you for reading,

Benjamin Hawley
